reviews.author: Emily
reviews.text:
I took the 6:45pm night tour today. No audio, just the city loud, glowing, chaotic, and beautiful. Hanoi‚Äôs traffic was wild but strangely fascinating.
I had many curious questions, and Anna, the staff, was a delight smart, funny, and charming. Her answers made me laugh and think. Tonight wasn‚Äôt just sightseeing. It was real. And I‚Äôll remember Anna as much as the city itself‚Ä¶

reviews.author: Ph∆∞∆°ng Mai
reviews.text:
I joined the sightseeing bus today at 11:15 AM and had such a lovely time. The open-top deck gave great views of Hanoi‚Äôs charming streets and historic spots.

It was hot, but Ngoc ‚Äì a friendly staff member ‚Äì offered me a sun hat, checked if I was okay, and reminded us to watch for low tree branches. She was always smiling and made everyone feel cared for.

After the ride, she even suggested a local ph·ªü place (it was amazing!) and gave tips on hidden temples and a caf√© by the lake. Ngoc truly made my day. I hope to see her again ‚Äì and come back to Hanoi soon.

reviews.author: Jordan Hal
reviews.text: The staff named Minh on the bus was very enthusiastic, the driver drove smoothly, the bus was very clean, however there were some problems: the outside of the bus was very dirty, some buses did not have the company logo so I could not find it. I saw the staff rewraping the used headphones and continuing to give them to me to use, was it clean? I wondered why the ticket price was not cheap but I could not use new headphones and maps.

reviews.author: Ary Damar
reviews.text:
Such a fun and relaxing way to explore Hanoi! I really enjoyed sitting on the top deck ‚Äî the breeze, the views, and the vibe were perfect. The route covered all the must-see spots like the Old Quarter, West Lake, and Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum.

The audio guide was informative, and the staff were friendly and helpful. I loved the freedom to hop off and explore, then hop back on whenever I wanted. Highly recommended for first-time visitors or anyone who wants a chill overview of the city!

reviews.author: Ph·∫°m H·ªìng Ng·ªçc
reviews.text: The trip was truly wonderful. I took the 6:45 PM ride. The weather was cool and breezy, and the staff, especially Minh, was very helpful. My kids also had a great time. I highly recommend the experience! I‚Äôll definitely come back next time‚Ä¶

name: Hanoi Old Quarter
editorialSummary: Historic trading district with a night market, narrow lanes, food hawkers & hotchpotch tube houses.
address: P. H√†ng Ngang, H√†ng ƒê√†o, Ho√†n Ki·∫øm, H√† N·ªôi 100000, Vietnam

reviews.author: Jon Heffer
reviews.text: We stayed in the Hanoi Old Quarter and it was nothing short of amazing!  We experienced the people, culture and atmosphere of the Old Quarter.  Walking through the busy streets was both exhilarating and quite the adventure navigating people, cars and motorcycles.  It was a rush!  The people are friendly, kind and welcoming and some became like family.  I HIGHLY recommend staying at a hotel in the Old Quarter and experiencing it for yourself.

reviews.author: Thanoj kumar
reviews.text:
Hanoi Old Quarter is a lively area full of history, culture, and bustling local life. The narrow streets are lined with shops selling clothes, souvenirs, handicrafts, and much more. Bargaining is common here‚Äîif you negotiate politely, prices can drop significantly, so good bargaining skills really help!

It‚Äôs best to visit in the morning or evening for a more comfortable walk. The atmosphere is energetic and offers a true glimpse into Hanoi‚Äôs local charm.

reviews.author: Richard Tan
reviews.text:
Visited a few years ago with my family. It was an eye opener because on Fri Sat and Sun evenings, all the roads were closed for people to enjoy.

And it is organised by section, with each section catering to the interests of different age groups.

Toddlers can drive toy cars and play uno stackers on the closed roads.

Kids a little older can do arts and crafts and play games.

Teenagers and young adults can dance and sing with their instruments or busker, play ball games, play chartek, tug of war or just sit around to chill with their pets.

Older adults and elderly have their own sections to do rock and roll and ballroom dancing.

And much more.

I felt the community spirit as the local people reached out to welcome me to join in and i did.

We should have this in all cities to promote social harmony.

There are many shops, cafes, eateries and very beautiful hotels (local and international) in the old quarters. I recommend staying there over the weekends and in local hotels. The service and food are impeccable.

reviews.author: Arief Budiman Ustiawan
reviews.text: Hanoi‚Äôs Old Quarter is a lively, historic district full of charm. Its narrow streets, old buildings, street food stalls, and traditional shops offer a true taste of Vietnamese culture. From sipping egg coffee to exploring local markets, it‚Äôs a must-visit area for anyone wanting to experience the soul of Hanoi.

reviews.author: Gautam
reviews.text: This is the place where almost all of Hanoi's landmarks are situated within a waking distance. Old and quaint houses and buildings dot this area intersected by narrow lanes. The old quarter hosts money exchanges, beer street, night market, and other landmarks. You'd be well advised to find a hotel in this area if you wish to be in the heart of action.

reviews.author: Jefri Wu
reviews.text: "I was very impressed with Great Travel Vietnam's professionalism. They were responsive, patient in answering questions, and always ready to help. I felt very supported and safe throughout my trip. I will definitely use their services again in the future."

reviews.author: Aman Goyal
reviews.text: Tu is a really good travel agent. Always responsive and helpful. I booked my commute to and forth to Sa Pa and the Ha Long Bay cruise through her agency. Never had any problems with the booking, she was always helpful and responded quickly. Reasonable prices. Would highly suggest booking stuff through her!

reviews.author: Joppe Zinken
reviews.text: We booked a daytrip to halong bay for 3 people. When we booked it at the agency it was very clear what was included and what not, unlike booking on the internet. The next day we got picked up at our hotel in the old quarter of hanoi. Ha long bay is famous for it‚Äôs pearls and in the first activity they showed us how that process works. Then they brought us to the boat where we had a very good lunch. (vegetarian is an option if you want to) then we had some time on the upper deck to relax and afterwards had the second activity which was a short boat ride or kayaking whit beautiful sights. Then we went back to the boat and went to the biggest cave in halong bay which was extremely crowded, but that obviously isn‚Äôt the foult of the agency. Then we went to an island where you could go for a swim or do a hike to a place with beautiful views, which also was pretty crowded. To end the day we had a sunset party on the boat and got very lucky with a beautiful sunset after a cloudy day. Then we got back at the harbour and they dropped us off at our hotel again. All in all it was a very good experience and everything was well arranged. 10/10 would recommend

reviews.author: Jorden Cash
reviews.text:
We booked a Halong bay trip on Feb 6th and it was one of the most wonderful experience
Even tho we had pick up problem initially , they suggest what's the best option and tried to accommodate as best as possible. The lady at the reception is the sweetest person I've ever seen. Very acknowledgeable and fun to talk to. Bedside their currency exchange rate is pretty good too.

reviews.author: David Pino
reviews.text:
I booked Ha Giang Loop with them.

The tour was and amazing experience, all the landscapes were incredible. The tour guides and the drivers were also pleasant and helpful in any moment.

About the accommodation and food, no problems with that.

Every moment ready from the agency to solve the problems that can appear during the tour, and not just before it.

reviews.author: Hani D. S
reviews.text:
Very lively and vibrant at night. Arrived at around 6:40pm and caught the 7:30pm train. I sat at Coffee no.74. There were still plenty of shops with plenty of tables available at the time. I searched it on google map then followed the direction from my hotel and entered through the shops. There will be store employees trying to pull you to their shops but just say no if you don‚Äôt want to. Personally I think all shops are about the same. We‚Äôre not there for the food anyway although we still had to order something to sit.

It gets crowded closer to the train time so it‚Äôs better if you can make a reservation. I couldn‚Äôt find the phone number of the coffee shop though, that‚Äôs why I arrived early. Food prices are on the pricier side and there will be peddlers trying to sell their goods while you‚Äôre sitting. Worth visiting even when you can‚Äôt catch a train.

reviews.author: Han Luu
reviews.text:
Unique experience in a very friendly, local yet chic area. I love their decorations and vibe.

We visited No 20 coffee shop, the owners were very warm, sincere and attention.

They have train schedule hanging in front of the coffee shops. About 10 minutes before the train showed up, they will give warning and help everyone to get ready. It's truly a one of a life time experience.

reviews.author: Caz
reviews.text:
We were staying a few streets away from Train street so ended up going a good few times during the day and the evening. We loved the atmosphere. It was great and something you'd never see in the UK.
We had no trouble just walking in and along the tracks and finding different coffee shops.
The owners made sure we were sat right back and were great. A must see if you are in Hanoi.

reviews.author: Mint Napatsarin
reviews.text:
Such a fun and unique spot in Hanoi! It‚Äôs a lively little market set right along the train tracks, with cozy bars and cafes lining both sides. I highly recommend grabbing a drink, chilling out, and waiting for the train to come through  just don‚Äôt forget to check the schedule!

The trains usually pass around 3:30 PM, 7:00 PM, and the last one is around 10:00 PM (give or take). The train only takes a few minutes to pass, but the excitement is next level! It comes so close that your heart will race. it‚Äôs an amazing and unforgettable experience. Definitely a must-do in Hanoi!

reviews.author: Mohamed Aslam
reviews.text: Unlike the train market in Bangkok, Hanoi‚Äôs night market was far better in every aspect. Especially at night, it looked absolutely stunning with vibrant lights and lively energy. There were plenty of souvenir shops, eateries, and caf√©s to explore. A beautiful, free place to stroll around and soak in the atmosphere.

name: Ceramic mosaic mural road
address: 11 P. H√†ng V√¥i, L√Ω Th√°i T·ªï, Ho√†n Ki·∫øm, H√† N·ªôi, Vietnam

reviews.author: Aria Phuong Anh
reviews.text:
The Ceramic Mosaic Mural is truly beautiful‚Äîcrafted with great care and attention to detail. Walking along this wall feels like witnessing the flow of Vietnam‚Äôs history through art. I was deeply impressed by the mural‚Äôs storytelling and the incredible talent of the Vietnamese artisans behind it.

However, the piece is not perfectly preserved. In some areas, the ceramic tiles are chipped or covered in dust. Despite that, it remains a meaningful and impressive cultural work worth visiting.

reviews.author: Saida Khalikova
reviews.text: It is not worth visiting. You need to cross highway with intensive traffic and walking along also is not pleasant because of traffic. I even didn‚Äôt make photos, really it wasn‚Äôt worth visiting(((

reviews.author: Jim Reaugh
reviews.text:
So, I took a stroll down this mural road, and let me tell you, it‚Äôs like if a Picasso painting decided to go for a walk and got really ambitious. This place is a visual spectacle, an explosion of color and creativity that‚Äôll make you think, ‚ÄúWhy isn‚Äôt my neighborhood this cool?‚Äù

The murals stretch for what feels like an eternity, turning an ordinary street into a vibrant gallery of ceramic art. It‚Äôs like the city took a giant arts and crafts project and just went for it. You‚Äôve got everything from quirky designs to historical scenes, all crafted with impressive detail. It‚Äôs a great way to turn your daily walk into an art appreciation class.

The craftsmanship is top-notch, and it‚Äôs clear that a lot of love and effort went into this project. It‚Äôs not just a mural; it‚Äôs an outdoor celebration of art and culture that makes you wonder why more cities don‚Äôt get in on this action.

If you‚Äôre in Hanoi and you want to see something truly unique, this place is where you need to go. It‚Äôs a colorful, eye-catching experience that‚Äôll make you appreciate how a bit of creativity can transform the everyday into something extraordinary.

reviews.author: James Z
reviews.text: Nice place to take pictures. My partner and I enjoyed par of the walk (the whole walk is 5-6km) although it is a bit chaotic due to the traffic. There is a bridge to cross the road. The quality of the mosaic is good and it makes it an interesting place to take alternative picture

reviews.author: Danny Hyun
reviews.text:
It is a railroad village in Hanoi, and there are many pretty cafes along the railroad tracks.  You can see many people taking pictures and drinking tea with the train tracks in the background.
Enjoying a leisurely drink on the railroad tracks is a different experience.  Even when the train is not passing by, the surrounding atmosphere is romantic.
It is recommended to enjoy a cup of coffee while watching many tourists.  It is a 15-minute walk from Hoan Kiem Lake.
Access is restricted due to road safety issues, but you can enter on condition that you drink a drink at the cafe.

reviews.author: c kwak
reviews.text: The view of the railway was nice, and watching the train pass by was quite a unique experience. Evening was better for photos than daytime, thanks to the lights. On the first day, we ended up drinking overpriced, tasteless coffee because no trains came at the expected times. The next day, we visited around 9 p.m. and finally got to see a train. The coffee was expensive, likely due to the seats that offer a close view of the trains, but honestly, it didn‚Äôt taste great. On the last day, we waited behind the gate to catch sight of the train at the scheduled time.

This very house, 14 Nguyen Gia Thieu street, is the house I used to live since I was born in 1968 till 1972.
I don‚Äôt recall much of a memory living in Hanoi, but these old pictures show us the good time we‚Äôve had during our staying, despite of the air raid which could happen at any moment. Yes I lived in the war era where air raids and hiding inside the shelter is a daily routine in life.

reviews.author: Marcellino Adryan
reviews.text:
SCBD Weekland is a vibrant bazaar hosting a multitude of food stalls, ample seating, live music, and captivating decorations, running until the new year. The diversity of food options here is impressive. I had the chance to try several dishes like tahu gejrot for 25k, beef gyoza for 30k, bakso Malang for 45k, nasi uduk for 35k, and donuts priced at 6k each.

The culinary offerings showcased a range of flavors, but the standout dishes were the tahu gejrot and beef gyoza, both incredibly delicious. The event is a food haven, offering a variety of delectable options to suit different tastes. With its lively ambiance, it's a recommended spot to unwind after work, indulge in good food, and soak in the festive atmosphere until the year ends.

This is a little oasis by the famous Tokyo tower. It looks like there are some maple trees growing. There are signs indicating what types of trees of autumn leaves are. And the centerpiece of it is a waterfall designed by a landscaper Yasuhei Nagaoka.
It‚Äôs already beautiful without maple leaves. I think I would definitely come back in autumn.

reviews.text: It‚Äôs a small park but gives an interesting perspective to Tokyo Tower. There are benches for tired feet, peaceful place to relax. Adjacent to Tokyo Tower.

reviews.text: Just around and off the side of Tokyo Tower, this local park must be so nice in the fall with the changing Japanese maple leaves. Nice bench seating, a solar clock, and a couple sign boards to explain the maples.  These ‚Äúpocket parks‚Äù so nice In the big city.

reviews.text: Quitely looking around and find a place so nice to visit. Mimiji not yet change it color but for sure it will be a good spot to amaze the different kind of. Easily to find cause near by the subway.

name: Shinjuku Golden-Gai
editorialSummary: Festive, popular city district famed for its narrow, winding alleys & numerous snug taverns.
address: 1 Chome-1 Kabukicho, Shinjuku City, Tokyo 160-0021

reviews.author: Tamas Kalosi
reviews.text:
It‚Äôs a very atmospheric and enjoyable place to have a few drinks and chat with others.
There are many bars ‚Äî some great, some not so much ‚Äî so it‚Äôs worth exploring a bit to find the right spot.
Even if you don‚Äôt plan to go inside anywhere, it‚Äôs still worth visiting and walking around to soak in the vibe.
Definitely a nighttime activity.

reviews.author: Anne Lysa
reviews.text: Golden-Gai is such an iconic spot in Tokyo. I‚Äôve been here so many times and always find a new little micro bar to try ‚Äì it‚Äôs fun and full of atmosphere. Yes, there are a lot of tourists these days, but locals still come too. Most places have a service charge, which I think is totally fair. These are tiny bars run by individuals, and if we want places like this to survive, we should support them. It‚Äôs a special little corner of Tokyo that really deserves it.

reviews.author: Cat HK
reviews.text:
Came here during daytime to check out these one-of-a-kind famous narrow alleys lined with cozy tiny bars and restaurants.

We picked one which had a cute Fatty Zoo Cat stuffed doll at door front. Lady staff was super friendly, we had a few drinks and really enjoyed the intimate atmosphere.

It was not busy when we went but night scene would totally be different vibe. Worth a visit.

reviews.author: A&L
reviews.text:
Everything is pretty full and you can expect to pay a cover charge for most spots. Was looking forward to doing a couple bars here, as I remember this from my last Tokyo trip, but ended up disappointed. Likely because I knew better this time. There are way better spots to find little bars or izakayas. Come here to check it out, but don‚Äôt think this is the best spot for little bars.

We found a cool bar, met some locals and tourists, had some drinks with the bartender, etc. but we have done that and more/better in other areas.

This review is not reflective of the bar we went to though, I left a separate review for that. Great time.

reviews.author: Zeus
reviews.text: Really cool area full of tiny bars downstairs little alleyways. Really would recommend visiting even if you don‚Äôt plan to go into the bars, it‚Äôs just a cool place to visit. Loads of different Japanese whiskeys which I love!

reviews.text: Went there on the weekend at 2pm was expecting to see cool cars. Seen several and had snack at the cafe. Stay for the view of the Gingko trees and hope to see when it turn yellow in autumn

reviews.text: The leaves are dried in December, but the Christmas market is really the next best event here. You have to pay ¬•1000 to enter the Christmas market. But it's worth it if you are a tourist... the experience is priceless.

reviews.text: At the last 2 weeks of November , should be the best time to go to the Meiji Jingu Outer Garden to see the yellow leaves of the Ginkgo trees . One of the best place to see the yellow leaves in Tokyo .    Thousands of people came to see the yellow leaves.  both the yellow Ginkgo trees & the flows of visitors became part of the Garden.  It's really beautiful to be surrounded by the yellow leaves. To go there is easy, only a 4 minutes from the subway station " Â§ñËãëÂâç " G 03.

reviews.author: Arvin
reviews.text:
We were fortunate to visit this sight during the autumn peak of gingko trees. The trees were yellow aligned along the street and were absolutely phenomenal!

Day time was not enough, so we revisited this sight within their time allotted for autumn leaves illumination. It was spectacular! It was a sight to behold. They close half of the street within the period, where it would last until 730 in the evening.

It was a great experience! Definitely highly recommended to visit during autumn. üòä

name: Godzilla Statue
editorialSummary: Public sculpture of the iconic giant mutant lizard from the long-running Japanese film series.
address: 1-ch≈çme-3-2 Y≈´rakuch≈ç, Chiyoda City, Tokyo 100-0006

reviews.author: Nehal Ahmed
reviews.text:
This is a smaller size Godzilla statue sitting on top of an underground parking lot. Dedicated to the statue, it‚Äôs called Godzilla Square in Hibiya. It is super clean and well maintained.

A lot of people sit around for resting or eating. We saw multiple restaurants in close proximity, Wendy‚Äôs and Tim Ho Wan, to name a few. Somewhat popular with tourists, we saw few groups taking photos with the statue and the sign. If you are a Godzilla fan, don‚Äôt forget to make a short stop here to get your picture.

reviews.author: Phredie
reviews.text: We were expecting a much bigger statue and nearly missed it if I hadn‚Äôt looked up behind me. This is a relatively small scale statue that is perched on top of a small building entrance. Although the statue is smaller than expected the details on it are quite good. If you‚Äôre a Godzilla fan you should probably make an effort to check it out.

reviews.author: Andrew DeVerse
reviews.text:
Fun little find to see and take a photo with. A little underwhelming. In your head you make up Godzilla to have a much larger effect. It is also perched upon a structure so you can‚Äôt capture the best angles of you want photos.

Still a fun little find on of Tokyo‚Äôs little Easter egg finds.

reviews.author: Anthony M
reviews.text: Pretty cool statue of Shin Godzilla. The statue itself is about 6-8 feet tall but still worth it. The park its in Hibuya is really nice and typically has other cinema related events going on.

reviews.author: Aneesh Damodharan
reviews.text: The Godzilla statue at Hibiya Godzilla Square, just outside Hibiya Station, is a must-see for fans of the iconic monster. Standing at 3 meters tall, this detailed Shin Godzilla (2016) statue is Japan‚Äôs largest full-body Godzilla figure, perched on a dramatic base that evokes the creature‚Äôs destructive nature. Its intricate design captures the menacing essence of the kaiju, making it a striking photo spot, especially when lit up at night. However, its relatively small size compared to the towering buildings around it can feel underwhelming for some, and the inability to get close due to its elevated position may disappoint those seeking creative angles

name: Spain-zaka Slope
address: 16-15 Udagawach≈ç, Shibuya, Tokyo 150-0042

reviews.author: Desi Daily
reviews.text:
In a quieter part of Shibuya, Japan, there's a sloped pedestrian alley called Spain-zaka, which translates to "Spanish Slope." This charming backstreet exudes an exotic, international vibe that stands out from the typical modern Japanese style of Shibuya. Located along Inokashira-dori, just north of the bustling Shibuya Scramble Crossing, Spain-zaka stretches about 100 meters and connects Inokashira-dori to Shibuya PARCO in the Koen-dori area, with stairs near the top of the slope.

Despite its short length, Spain-zaka is an exciting destination, offering one of Japan's rare sloped shopping streets with a distinctly foreign atmosphere. It's the perfect spot to spend an afternoon enjoying a caf√© visit, soaking in the scenery, or grabbing a drink and taking a leisurely stroll. Here‚Äôs a list of cafes to explore while visiting Spain-zaka!

reviews.author: Wolf Fivousix
reviews.text: When planning my visit to Tokyo this place come up multiple times. What a joke. It's literally a set of stairs with a few overpriced stores around. If you are in the area, by all means, walk it, but definitely do not waste your time for this.

reviews.author: Heng Look
reviews.text: After walking it we wondered if we passed it because the slope was so underwhelming. We walked back and it didn‚Äôt appear any more impressive.

reviews.author: Fabrice Symonds
reviews.text: Nothing particularly special about this alley we found on the way to Parco for Nintendo store but we had LOADS of fun in the small photo/video booth hidden in bend near the top. You also get access to an online time lapse video of your prep for each photo which is very funny to watch.

reviews.author: Piotr
reviews.text: You can find few nice restaurants and shops on this street but why this place is tourist attraction in don't have idea

name: Yoyogi Park Zelkova Trees
address: 1-ch≈çme-5-11 Jinnan, Shibuya, Tokyo 150-0041

reviews.author: Christopher Gorrie
reviews.text: It‚Äôs a nice walkway that leads up to Yoyogi Park from Shibuya. The walkway is flanked by the well-known trees. It‚Äôs clearly maintained and the trees are beautiful. I believe this place is very eye-catching during the holidays when they illuminate everything with special lights. On a regular day, it looks nice, and is a nice walk, but isn‚Äôt necessarily the most incredible experience. A good walk near Shibuya all the same.

reviews.author: Jennifer Scanlon
reviews.text:
No filter. It's just that darn blue. This park is absolutely breathtaking during the holiday illuminations. There are tons of people there so it can be crowded getting to the park itself, however, the crowd disperses a bit once you're inside the park. There were several food trucks and stands available for food and drink. I still don't understand why people are getting ice cream when it's cold, but whatever? LOL not really my thing. I went for some hot chocolate instead!
It's December 2024, and one of the videos that played on the Snow dome was of a Santa Claus that was kind of sexy? But he was selling pasta? I don't even know. It was great. I had a really nice time, even though it was just me on my own. Lots of couples here, lots of families, lots of people with friends. It seems like a great time with a lot of people, but it's also fun when you're solo. I had read somewhere that you could see Tokyo Tower from this location, but I think it was hidden by a large construction wall. I could definitely see this illumination from the top of Tokyo Tower when I was up there the night before. This is definitely a must-see event if you are here in the fall. It does not disappoint. Will absolutely be back.
On that note, Tokyo knows how to do Christmas.
Technically, this park is handicap accessible. I walk with a cane, and very slowly. The crowds can be a bit much as you're coming through Shibuya. But, if you're willing to fight the crowds, this is definitely worth seeing. It's positioned right in between Harajuku station and Shibuya station, but I recommend coming from Shibuya station so that you can see the full illuminations all the way up the road. It is a steep hill for those with mobility needs. So, if you are in a wheelchair, maybe bring a friend with you to help get you up the hill. I was quite exhausted walking up it after being on my feet all day, with my cane. And, with the crowds, it can be really difficult to navigate. Come prepared and play it safe and you'll be just fine. üëç

reviews.author: Muhamad Verrell
reviews.text: Very nice park with a few ponds which makes it more aesthetically pleasing. They got bathroom and tap water too. Bring your kids here because it‚Äôs way more fun with family or loved ones. It‚Äôs pretty massive so make sure you have lots of energy to explore the whole park! If you‚Äôre hungry or craving for some food, you can also find some small caf√© here.

name: Pelican Fountains
address: 1 Hibiyakoen, Chiyoda City, Tokyo 100-0012

reviews.author: KIICHIRO KOBORI
reviews.text:
The agave lily (ry≈´zetsuran) has bloomed in Hibiya Park!

The agave lily is said to bloom only once every few decades.
This rare flower can be seen in Hibiya Park in central Tokyo. This time, the flower that bloomed is a blue rhododendron located beside the Pelican Fountain in Hibiya Park's First Flower Garden.

Flowering was confirmed on July 10, and its height was measured on the following day, July 11, at 7.7 meters.

We began measuring its height in mid-May, and at the beginning of the measurement, it was growing about 10 cm per day, but just before flowering, the growth almost stopped.

The delicate yellow flowers have begun to bloom in order from the buds at the bottom, and as of July 11, approximately 20% of the total flowers have bloomed.
The upper buds are expected to continue blooming for about a month, so please take this opportunity to visit Hibiya Park!

reviews.author: T. GeBrim
reviews.text: Around 280 street trees are decorated with 820,000 champagne-gold coloured light bulbs, and the event also features a Christmas market and food stalls. Held since 2002, the illuminations were created with the aim of boosting tourism, and last year over 7.5 million people visited during the period.

reviews.author: ÈΩäËó§ÂÆü
reviews.text: Marunouchi illuminations are one of the things to look forward to every winter. The trees along Marunouchi Nakadori are decorated with elegant champagne gold lights, creating a sophisticated and adult atmosphere. Walking along the glittering tree-lined avenue naturally warms your heart and makes you feel like you're spending a special night. The window displays of commercial facilities are also elaborate, so it's recommended to stop by after shopping. Combined with the illuminations of Tokyo Station, it makes for a great photo spot. It's a classic winter spot that's perfect for dates and strolls with friends.

reviews.author: ÊÑâÂø´„Å™„Çπ„Éä„Éï„Ç≠„É≥
reviews.text:
Marunouchi Illuminations

I walked from Yurakucho to Nijubashi on my way home from work. The city was filled with a Christmas mood. I had some hot cocoa and it warmed my body and soul! (Visited December 21, 2023)

Tokyo Misty Las 2021

I took a short detour on my way home from work. I came to see the illuminations at Tokyo Station! People gather to see the beautiful light art, but it seems to be much emptier than usual. I mingled with the young people and mourned the passing of the year with the people of the city. (Visited December 21, 2021)

reviews.author: „Éü„É©„Éª„Éì„É™„ÇπÔºàmirabiliusÔºâ
reviews.text:
This winter illumination takes place every year from late November to mid-February of the following year, and involves the whole of Marunouchi.

It is one of the world's largest city-wide illuminations in terms of both the number of lights and the scale of the decorations.

Depending on the year, collaborations with various content such as Disney and Mario are held, so it's fun to look forward to what will happen each year.

The photo I'm posting this time is from 2023, but illuminations and special events are not only held on the main street, but also in many buildings.

Also, if you continue walking along the main street towards Hibiya and Shimbashi, you can reach the Hibiya illuminations, making it a great place for a date or a walk.

There are many cafes, restaurants, and bars, so it's recommended to take a break and stroll around.

This is an illumination event that takes over the entire Marunouchi area, held annually from late November to mid-February of the following year.

As one of the world's largest illuminations in terms of the number of lights

name: Godzilla Statue

address: 1-ch≈çme-3-2 Y≈´rakuch≈ç, Chiyoda City, Tokyo 100-0006

reviews.author: Nehal Ahmed
reviews.text:
This is a smaller size Godzilla statue sitting on top of an underground parking lot. Dedicated to the statue, it‚Äôs called Godzilla Square in Hibiya. It is super clean and well maintained.

A lot of people sit around for resting or eating. We saw multiple restaurants in close proximity, Wendy‚Äôs and Tim Ho Wan, to name a few. Somewhat popular with tourists, we saw few groups taking photos with the statue and the sign. If you are a Godzilla fan, don‚Äôt forget to make a short stop here to get your picture.

reviews.author: Phredie
reviews.text: We were expecting a much bigger statue and nearly missed it if I hadn‚Äôt looked up behind me. This is a relatively small scale statue that is perched on top of a small building entrance. Although the statue is smaller than expected the details on it are quite good. If you‚Äôre a Godzilla fan you should probably make an effort to check it out.

reviews.author: Andrew DeVerse
reviews.text:
Fun little find to see and take a photo with. A little underwhelming. In your head you make up Godzilla to have a much larger effect. It is also perched upon a structure so you can‚Äôt capture the best angles of you want photos.

Still a fun little find on of Tokyo‚Äôs little Easter egg finds.

reviews.author: Anthony M
reviews.text: Pretty cool statue of Shin Godzilla. The statue itself is about 6-8 feet tall but still worth it. The park its in Hibuya is really nice and typically has other cinema related events going on.

reviews.author: Aneesh Damodharan
reviews.text: The Godzilla statue at Hibiya Godzilla Square, just outside Hibiya Station, is a must-see for fans of the iconic monster. Standing at 3 meters tall, this detailed Shin Godzilla (2016) statue is Japan‚Äôs largest full-body Godzilla figure, perched on a dramatic base that evokes the creature‚Äôs destructive nature. Its intricate design captures the menacing essence of the kaiju, making it a striking photo spot, especially when lit up at night. However, its relatively small size compared to the towering buildings around it can feel underwhelming for some, and the inability to get close due to its elevated position may disappoint those seeking creative angles

reviews.author: gaby guri
reviews.text:
huo-dori Avenue, located in the heart of Ginza, Tokyo, is one of the most iconic and upscale shopping streets in Japan. Stretching roughly one kilometer, this avenue is the center of Ginza's luxury district and is lined with flagship stores, high-end boutiques, gourmet restaurants, and large department stores. On
weekends and holidays, the avenue is closed to vehicle traffic, turning it into a relaxed pedestrian zone where people can stroll freely, enjoy street performances, or sit at cafe-style tables set up in the middle of the road. Chuo-dori at night is a favorite for nighttime photography ‚Äî clean lines, glowing signage,
and the contrast of modern architecture with historic touches make it a visually rich location.

Takeshita  is another long street full of unique shops, activities, food and drinks store. It is right next to the Harajuku station. Here we got the see some of the unique places like Hello Kitty store, popular crepe store, Xing Fu Tang, Machi Machi, Petting store, Arcade stores and many other types that we didn‚Äôt find anywhere else in Tokyo.

The street is very crowded. It‚Äôs very hot and humid during summer. So make sure to bring umbrella and wear light clothing. We found some amazing souvenir shop here and bought few items. Most places take both cash and cards.  The Hello Kitty store had so many cool products. We had such a wonderful time walking down this street.

A vibrant pedestrian-only street in Harajuku that offers both kawaii and edgy fashion for the trend-conscious youths, quirky micro pig cafes, and plenty of insta-worthy food options.

Closer to Harajuku Station, there is also a McDonalds and a multi-level Daiso. The ground floor of Daiso is absolute chock-a-block, with tourists snapping up cute souvenirs.

Great spot for those who want to check out Japan's famous kawaii culture, but be prepared for the overwhelming crowds at times.

7/11.
The train station is right at the top end of the street so it's easy to get to or leave.

reviews.text:
One of the most famous streets of Harajuku. Famous for its cosplay walks, but in itself it is of undoubted interest for its isolation and special festive atmosphere.
On weekends it can be unusually crowded, but these are usually the days when you can meet the most colorful representatives of the cosplay tribe, the most interesting street musicians and see an unusually diverse crowd.

name: Baba Banda Singh Bahadur Statue
address: Metro Station Mandi House, Mandi House, New Delhi, Delhi 110001

reviews.author: Anil Kumar
reviews.text:
Great Banda Singh Bahadur (born Lachman Dev) (27 October 1670 ‚Äì 9 June 1716), was a Sikh warrior and a commander of the Khalsa army.

At age 15, he left home to become an ascetic, and was given the name Madho Das Bairagi. He established a monastery at NƒÅnded, on the bank of the river GodƒÅvarƒ´.

reviews.author: Sakshi Keshari
reviews.text:
I recently had the privilege of visiting the Baba Banda Singh Bahadur Statue in Delhi, and I must say that it left a lasting impression on me. As a history enthusiast, I was intrigued by the opportunity to pay homage to a figure as significant as Baba Banda Singh Bahadur, and the statue did justice to his monumental legacy.

The location of the statue itself is striking, situated in a serene and well-maintained park. The ambiance created by the surrounding greenery provides a tranquil setting that befits the stature of the historical figure it represents. The park also offers ample space for visitors to take a leisurely stroll, relax, or engage in conversations, adding to the overall pleasant experience.

The statue itself is a masterpiece of craftsmanship. Towering at an impressive height, it captures the essence of Baba Banda Singh Bahadur's strength and determination. The attention to detail is remarkable, from the intricately carved armor and weapons to the facial expression exuding confidence and fearlessness. It truly stands as a fitting tribute to a valiant warrior who played a pivotal role in Sikh history.

Moreover, the plaque and information boards placed near the statue provide valuable insights into the life and achievements of Baba Banda Singh Bahadur. They offer a glimpse into the historical context and significance of his contributions, enabling visitors to better understand the impact of his actions. The presence of knowledgeable guides who are eager to share their expertise and answer questions further enhances the educational experience.

I appreciated the cleanliness and maintenance of the surroundings, as well as the thoughtful amenities provided for visitors, such as seating areas and convenient pathways. The park staff were friendly and approachable, contributing to the warm and welcoming atmosphere.

The only minor suggestion I have is the availability of more information in multiple languages. While there was English signage, it would be beneficial to have translations in other widely spoken languages, as it would attract a more diverse range of visitors and make the historical narrative more accessible to all.

In conclusion, visiting the Baba Banda Singh Bahadur Statue was an enriching experience that combined art, history, and reverence. The statue itself is an awe-inspiring sight, and the surrounding park provides a serene setting for reflection and contemplation. Whether you are a history enthusiast, a follower of Sikhism, or simply someone interested in exploring the cultural heritage of India, I highly recommend a visit to this majestic tribute.

reviews.author: Arif Ansari
reviews.text: This is a very secure area and a little further ahead there is also a small park near the roundabout which is very beautiful.

reviews.author: Abdul Asif
reviews.text: Banda Singh Bahadur¬†(born¬†Lachman Dev)[3][1][4](27 October 1670 ‚Äì 9 June 1716,¬†Delhi), was a¬†Sikh¬†military commander who established a Sikh state with capital at¬†Lohgarh¬†(present-day¬†Haryana, India). At age 15 he left home to become an¬†ascetic, and was given the name ‚Äò‚ÄôMadho Das‚Äô‚Äô. He established a monastery at¬†NƒÅnded, on the bank of the river¬†GodƒÅvarƒ´, where in September 1708 he was visited by, and became a disciple of,¬†Guru Gobind Singh, who gave him the new name of Banda Singh Bahadur after¬†initiating¬†him into the¬†Khalsa. Armed with the blessing and authority of Guru Gobind Singh, he came to¬†Khanda¬†in¬†Sonipatand assembled a fighting force and led the struggle against the¬†Mughal Empire. Guru Gobind Singh also appointed five Sikhs (Baj Singh,¬†Binod Singh, Ram Singh, Daya Singh, Kahan Singh) to assist him.[5]

reviews.author: Tushar Khatri

This is the statue dedicated to one of the iconic figures in Sikhism - Baba Banda Singh Bahadur. Constructing such statues at important places of a city are important for the upcoming generations to remember them.
Such personalities have an important contribution in Indian history and it's our duty to pay the due respect to them.
One can get down at Mandi House metro station to see this statue. It is near to Mandi House Gol chakkar and one can see going from Barakhamba Road to Pragati Maidan or vice-versa.

reviews.author: Arjun K Ashokan
reviews.text: Yamuna Ghat is a peaceful escape from the chaos of the city. Especially magical at sunrise, when thousands of seagulls take flight over the calm river ‚Äî it‚Äôs a surreal, almost spiritual experience. Perfect for photography, reflection, or a quiet boat ride.

reviews.author: Sanz Barny
reviews.text: A quiet and serene place to visit in the morning. Yamuna water is black and murky as always. The blueness of the waters is because of the blue skies. Hire a boat for ‚Çπ1500 for an hour or 2. Many birds in the winter months that from November to February. It‚Äôs also a favourite spot for pre bridal photo shoots. Ample free parking available.

reviews.author: Abdul Al Muhammed Althaf
reviews.text:
üåßÔ∏è A Rainy Day at Yamuna Ghat ‚Äì A Magical Experience üåßÔ∏è

Visiting Yamuna Ghat on a rainy day was truly a mesmerizing experience. The rain added a poetic charm to the place, with the soft ripples on the river and the misty atmosphere making it feel almost surreal. The sound of the rain blending with the chants and the sight of birds flying low over the water was incredibly peaceful. It‚Äôs a perfect spot for photographers, nature lovers, or anyone looking for a quiet moment in the heart of Delhi. Definitely one of the most beautiful and underrated experiences in the city!

reviews.author: Ishu Rustagi
reviews.text:
Yamuna Ghat** is a peaceful riverside spot known for **beautiful sunrises** and **migratory seagulls** (best in winter: Nov‚ÄìFeb). Ideal for photographers, birdwatchers, and spiritual seekers.

‚úÖ **Pros**:

* Stunning sunrise views
* Boat rides with birds flying overhead
* Unique, peaceful vibe

‚ö†Ô∏è **Cons**:

* Polluted river and dirty surroundings
* Smell and litter can be off-putting
* Not well-maintained

üïî **Best time**: Sunrise (5:30‚Äì7‚ÄØAM), winter months
üéí **Tip**: Go early, bring a camera, and don‚Äôt expect luxury.

Not recommended in summers.

Maybe the sunrise is pretty and ecstatic but not for long as the direct sunlight will eventually start to penetrate your skin and eyes.

name: Naini Lake
address: Naini Lake, Block A 2, Model Town Phase I, Model Town, New Delhi, Delhi, 110033

reviews.author: Jitendra Menariya
reviews.text: Manini Lake is a serene and lesser-known gem, perfect for those seeking peace away from the tourist rush. The calm waters reflect the surrounding hills beautifully, offering a picturesque view. Boating is the main activity here, and gliding through the still lake feels truly refreshing. It‚Äôs also a great spot for nature photography and quiet walks along the banks. The air is fresh, the surroundings are clean, and the overall vibe is peaceful. A lovely place to relax and unwind in nature‚Äôs lap.

reviews.author: Sharik khan
reviews.text:
I visited here during Eid holidays, it was Tuesday. I experienced the boating first time with my friend. The experience was awesome when you enters boat and start boating by pedal. We choose pedal boating because of our budget, more timings (30 min, while motor boat will you ride 2 rounds of lake, 2 rounds will be completed within 10 min).
So if you want to truly enjoy boating time then choose pedal boating.
Pedal boating price is 130 (we were 2 person in rs 130)
I think its 130 for two persons or its 130 for a boat for 30 mins.
Motor boat ride ticket üé´ price is :250 rs. (I don't confirm that its per person or what)
After boating, you can walk around the area but you may find some couples here doing naughty things publically ü§¶.
My experience was awesome üòé, ticket price worth the money ü§ë, there was no room for submitting bags or luggage so we requested the staff to keep our bag for 30 mins and they replied "BOMB WOMB TOH NAHI HAI üëÄüòè"
Well, after request we submitted bag to their local staff room.
So if you want to experience boating in budget, don't think, go for it ‚ò∫Ô∏è.
Nearest metro üöá; MODEL TOWN
and then walking distance of 300 mtrs approx.

reviews.author: Nomadians
reviews.text: I‚Äôve been to nainital many times but it never ceases to amuse me. The lake, the wind, a different kind of calmness amidst the hustle bustle of tourists. Its truly is a place where one can easily get lost amongst thoughts. Plenty of food options to have including my favourite mutton momos available at Bhutia market just beside naina devi temple. Boating is a must if you are coming for the first time. Overall an experience which you will cherish for your lifetime.

reviews.author: Shafi Akram
reviews.text: Naini Lake is a hidden gem amidst the hustle and bustle of Delhi. Tucked away in the heart of Model Town, it's an unexpected oasis of tranquility. The lake offers a pleasant break from city life, especially if you‚Äôre nearby and want to unwind. While it may not be as expansive or scenic as some of the more popular lakes in hill stations, it definitely has its own charm.The highlight of Naini Lake is definitely the boating experience. They have a variety of boats to choose from, including paddle boats and rowing boats. It‚Äôs an ideal activity if you‚Äôre visiting with family or friends. Kids especially will have a great time paddling around and spotting birds around the lake. The calm waters, combined with the gentle rustling of trees around, make it a peaceful outing. Boating here can be a fun and relaxing way to spend an hour or two, especially during the early morning or late afternoon when the weather is cooler.However, Naini Lake is not necessarily a destination you'd plan a trip around. It's more of a "visit if you‚Äôre nearby" kind of place rather than a must-see attraction. The surroundings can get a bit crowded, especially on weekends, as it's located in a busy part of the city. If you‚Äôre someone who loves boating, this spot is worth a quick visit.Overall, Naini Lake offers a pleasant experience for those looking for a quick escape into nature without leaving the city. Definitely recommended if you happen to be in the area!

I do wish the surroundings were a little better-maintained, and that there was some signage explaining - even in just two lines, if not more - something about Nadira, Sulochana and Pramila, given that most people today wouldn't know anything about them.

reviews.author: Akshat Kumar
reviews.text:
Delhi Street Art is phenomenal, despite sadly being ignored by many people. These 3 portraits of Jewish ladies of Bollywood are tucked away in an area of Connaught Place which one chances upon while walking and seeing the richness of blue on the walls.

Nadira, Pramila and Sulochana‚Äîtheir portraits speak to you, beseeching almost, to research more about them, to look them closely and to appreciate the beauty that is art in general. If you chance upon these paintings, I ask that you observe them closely and look them up if you don‚Äôt know about these ladies.

As someone else mentioned, I wish they had some more information about the lives and works of these ladies. Oh well, I can dream.

Sadly it was our last night in Dehli before we ever met Dilip, so we wished maybe we could have ridden out on more occasions with him.
Thank you Dilip you made our evening.
We'll definitely look you up, next time we are in Dehli.
xx

reviews.author: Ankur Bagai
reviews.text:
The Yamuna River Viewing Point, in theory, should be a serene and spiritual location‚Äîa place to admire one of Hinduism‚Äôs holiest rivers. Unfortunately, the reality is far from ideal. Instead of being a peaceful retreat or a scenic landmark, it feels more like an ignored corner of the city, plagued by neglect, pollution, and poor maintenance.

Pros:
The only real merit of the spot lies in its intent. For residents of Delhi or those living nearby, it could be worth visiting once or twice out of curiosity or reverence. The historical and cultural significance of the Yamuna holds emotional value, especially for those who grew up with tales of its sacred past.

Cons:
However, any sense of holiness or serenity is quickly drowned by the overpowering stench and the visuals of the polluted river. The water is murky, with visible waste floating on the surface, and the surrounding area often resembles a neglected dumping ground more than a public viewing space.

The lack of civic responsibility from local visitors, combined with near-total inattention by the Delhi Government and municipal bodies, only makes the experience worse. There are no proper cleaning efforts, no tourist facilities, and no structured attempt to preserve or beautify the area.

When compared to the beautifully maintained ghats of the Ganga in Varanasi or Haridwar, the contrast is stark and disappointing. Those ghats invite reflection, devotion, and tourism. Yamuna River Viewing Point, sadly, offers none of that.

Conclusion:
The Yamuna River Viewing Point is a wasted opportunity. It could have been a beautiful symbol of Delhi‚Äôs spiritual and ecological heritage. Instead, it‚Äôs become a disheartening representation of urban neglect and environmental apathy. Unless major cleanup and restoration efforts are made, it‚Äôs hard to recommend this place to anyone‚Äîtourist or local.

address: WRJC+3QJ, Nariman Point, Mumbai, Maharashtra 400021

reviews.author: Vikash Kumar
reviews.text:
Marine Drive is truly the soul of Mumbai. Stretching along the Arabian Sea, this iconic promenade offers a perfect blend of calmness and city energy. The view of the sunset here is breathtaking‚Äîwatching the sky turn orange while waves hit the shore is an unforgettable experience.

At night, when the streetlights curve along the coastline, it transforms into the famous ‚ÄúQueen‚Äôs Necklace‚Äù, sparkling like a jewel from above. Whether you‚Äôre walking, sitting by the sea, or just enjoying the breeze, Marine Drive has a charm that makes you want to stay longer.

It‚Äôs clean, well-maintained, and safe for families, couples, and solo visitors alike. Street food vendors nearby add a local flavor‚Äînothing beats enjoying roasted corn or chai while listening to the sound of the waves. The only downside is traffic and parking around peak hours, but once you‚Äôre on the promenade, it all feels worth it.

reviews.author: BRISTIDEV BURMAN
reviews.text:
‚Ä¢A 3.6 km long boulevard in South Mumbai, running along the Arabian Sea.

‚Ä¢Also called the ‚ÄúQueen‚Äôs Necklace‚Äù because its streetlights resemble a string of pearls when viewed at night.

‚Ä¢Built in the 1920s, it connects Nariman Point to Girgaum Chowpatty Beach.

‚Ä¢Popular for evening walks, sea views, and street food.

‚Ä¢A favorite spot for locals, tourists, and filmmakers ‚Äî often featured in Bollywood movies.

‚Ä¢Known for its sunset views and as the heartbeat of Mumbai‚Äôs seaside lifestyle.

HOW TO REACH
‚Ä¢ Take train to Churchgate Station.....then 2 mins walking distance (easiest route)

NO TICKETS

Marine Drive is always bustling with people, yet it somehow manages to feel peaceful at the same time. The atmosphere is full of positive vibes, especially during the evening when the sea breeze kicks in.

It‚Äôs the kind of place where you can spend hours just sitting by the promenade, watching the waves and letting the ocean do the talking. Whether you‚Äôre alone or with friends, it‚Äôs a perfect spot to relax, reflect, and take in the view.

reviews.author: siddesh narvekar
reviews.text:
The Powai Dam is a major reservoir located in Powai, a suburb in the northeastern part of Mumbai, India. It was built in 1891 by the British colonial government to supply drinking water to the city of Mumbai.

The dam is constructed across the Mithi River and covers an area of about 2.1 square kilometers. It has a height of approximately 26 meters and a length of 1,450 meters. The reservoir created by the dam has a capacity of 545 million gallons (2.48 million cubic meters) of water.

The Powai Dam is surrounded by lush greenery and provides a picturesque view. It serves as a popular recreational spot for locals and tourists, offering opportunities for boating and fishing activities. The dam also plays a crucial role in flood control, as it helps regulate the water flow during heavy rains.

Over the years, the Powai Dam has become an important landmark in Mumbai, attracting visitors with its serene atmosphere and scenic beauty. It is considered a significant source of water supply for the city and plays a vital role in meeting the water demands of its residents.

reviews.author: Adam Bardon

Beautiful, vibrant and meaningful murals, who would have thought that it would make a fine addition to a previously bleak place.

They also added infographics on LED TVs on the area which spreads information to the general public.

Kudos Manila LGU.

reviews.author: Danny Hyun
reviews.text:
The Lagusnilad Underpass is a pedestrian walkway that connects Manila City Hall to the historic site of Intramuros.
Manila is the center of industrial development in the Philippines and has a large workforce that continues to contribute to economic growth.
In order to encourage and motivate these modern-day heroes, the City of Manila and the Cultural Heritage Conservation Agency have collaborated to incorporate labor as a major theme in restoration and beautification projects throughout the metropolitan area.

First on the left is a panoramic mural that spans the Philippines‚Äô pre-colonial and contemporary history. Through it, we can sense memories and even catastrophes from our special past.
This mural reflects important turning points in history such as the Philippine‚ÄìAmerican War, the First Quarter storm from January 26 to March 17, 1970, and the struggle against the Marcos dictatorship. Through the murals, the artist pays tribute to and commemorates notable figures in history while also paying tribute to and respecting modern-day heroes (doctors, nurses, police officers, etc.) who led the fight on the front lines against the COVID-19 pandemic. It also aims to reaffirm the pride and identity of Filipinos.

The bas sculpture on the right wall depict workers in various fields (farmers, fishermen, engineers, construction workers, office workers, etc.) and express gratitude and admiration for their hard work.
It was created by Guerrilla, a group formed at the College of Arts of The University of the Philippines (UP), the country's top university.

reviews.text: The new Manila underpass is a game-changer for city commuters. Its modern design and efficient traffic flow significantly reduce congestion, making travel smoother and faster. reviews.text:
This tourist hotspot lives up to its reputation. Yes, it's crowded and commercial, but the experience justifies the visit. You'll find plenty of souvenir shops and quick dining options scattered throughout.

Timing matters‚Äîvisit early or late to avoid the heaviest crowds. Don't skip the historical information available on-site. Learning the backstory makes the visit much more meaningful.

Worth the trip despite the touristic feel.

reviews.text:
This is considered the super artsy street but it's very touristy (and not artsy in my opinion). I was imagining more local artists and murals and such. Lots of branded stuff but definitely more local than a mall. I saw maybe 3 tour groups when here by myself. Overpriced area but nice to walk. Can't say that I'd come again.

People do live in the neighborhood so please be respectful of noise and such!

The sellers are really nice and they comprised of small stores of all variety of items you could and couldn't think of. If you have chance, dropby any tea house and they will offer you a cup of tea. After that, you will be captivated with their tea and you will buy.. üòÜ frankly the items are really affordable and not overly priced.

reviews.text:
This was one of our favorite spots in Shanghai. The shops here were surprisingly unique and didn‚Äôt feel as repetitive as in other touristy areas.

The atmosphere was relaxed and had a great vibe overall. The walkways are quite narrow, so I can imagine it gets pretty hectic on weekends. We visited on a Friday morning and found the crowds manageable, even little to some extent.

editorialSummary: Compact area of cobbled alleyways renowned for the colorful graffiti decorating its walls.

reviews.author: Gaurav Jha
reviews.text:
Beco do Batman in Vila Madalena is a must-see if you like street art or just want to feel S√£o Paulo‚Äôs creative pulse. It‚Äôs not big‚Äîjust a few alleys‚Äîbut every wall is alive with murals that change constantly. Some are loud and political, others just wild bursts of color. The art isn‚Äôt locked behind glass; it‚Äôs raw, textured, and right at your fingertips.

It can get crowded, especially on weekends when photographers, tourists, and live painters all pack the space. But that‚Äôs part of the vibe‚Äîit feels more like a living, breathing gallery than a tourist stop. Go early in the morning if you want cleaner shots and fewer people. Good shoes help on the cobblestones.

reviews.author: Scott Moen
reviews.text: This was a pleasant surprise. This area was on our list of places to visit while in S√£o Paulo but was low on our list. We finally visited on our last day as a ‚Äútime killer‚Äù before the airport. We thoroughly enjoyed our experience. Fun neighborhood with great energy, fun art everywhere and good food options. We visited during the week and mid day. It was not busy and very comfortable. I would recommend it.

reviews.author: John Stewart, Jr.
reviews.text:
üìç Vila Madalena, S√£o Paulo, Brazil
üì∏ Coordinates: -23.5614, -46.6911
üé® Postcards & Coordinates

Step into a living canvas in Vila Madalena, where every wall speaks in color, protest, memory, and celebration. This bohemian enclave in S√£o Paulo pulses with the rhythm of graffiti, samba, and soul, transforming alleyways into open-air museums of resistance and creativity.

From the iconic Beco do Batman‚Äîa world-renowned graffiti alley‚Äîto the murals of artists like Eduardo Kobra, Os G√™meos, and Nina Pandolfo, this neighborhood is more than a photo op. It‚Äôs a claimed space where artists shape public dialogue and identity, layer by layer, spray by spray.

Here, art isn‚Äôt locked behind glass. It‚Äôs alive. It whispers stories of politics, play, love, and local pride. üåà‚úä

What can you learn here?
üëÄ How color becomes commentary.
üß† How public space becomes personal.
üí¨ How cities breathe through the voices of their artists.

‚ú® A must-visit for every traveler seeking more than just sights‚Äîcome for the art, stay for the soul.

Conhecido por ser o maior reduto da comunidade japonesa na cidade, o bairro encanta com suas ruas decoradas por lumin√°rias t√≠picas, lojas especializadas, restaurantes incr√≠veis e um com√©rcio efervescente. Al√©m de toda essa riqueza cultural, a Liberdade tem um charme especial, onde tradi√ß√£o e modernidade se encontram, tornando cada caminhada pelo bairro uma experi√™ncia memor√°vel e cheia de descobertas. üå∏üç£‚ú®

name: Arcos do Bixiga
address: R. Jandaia, 164 - Bela Vista, S√£o Paulo - SP, 01316-100

reviews.author: RB
reviews.text:
Remanescente arquitetural da S√£o Paulo antiga, redescobertos em 1987 durante a prefeitura de J√¢nio Quadros. Foram constru√≠dos entre 1908 e 1913 sendo um extenso muro de tijolos que forma arcos e separados por pilastras tamb√©m de tijolos, seno o ponto mais alto a 11 metros de altura.

No final do s√©culo XIX fortes chuvas provocavam deslizamentos na regi√£o onde ficava a  Travessa Santa Cruz entre as ruas Jandaia e Assembl√©ia e devido a isto a prefeitura da √©poca (de  Asdr√∫bal Augusto do Nascimento) decidiu construir um muro de arrimo, contratando imigrantes italianos.

Com o crescimento urbano e sem os deslizamentos, corti√ßos foram sendo constru√≠dos bem a sua frente e cobrindo a estrutura, sem permiss√£o da prefeitura.

Mas nos anos 60 com o projeto de interliga√ß√£o da Avenida 23 de Maio e a rec√©m inaugurada Anel Leste-Oeste come√ßou um processo  de desapropria√ß√£o e demoli√ß√£o que devido a brigas com os propriet√°rios que demorou d√©cadas.

Finalmente em 1987 a situa√ß√£o foi resolvida e os arcos redescobertos, sendo o jardim a frente deles batizado de Pra√ßa dos Artes√£os Calabreses (Cal√°bria √© uma regi√£o da It√°lia), com o tombamento da estrutura sendo realizado em 2002.

Cr√©dito das fotos mais recentes, que mostram os corti√ßos: Paulo Tarrinaf (1940-2017, Site S√£o Paulo Antiga). Foto mais antiga com os arcos na era original: Fonte desconhecida.

reviews.author: Breno De Maio
reviews.text: Um pouco da velha arquitetura de S√£o Paulo que acidentalmente foi preservada. Durante a gest√£o de J√¢nio Quadros na prefeitura esse conjunto de arcos foi redescoberto (1987), restaurado e preservado at√© os dias atuais. Tamb√©m s√£o chamados de os "arcos do J√¢nio", e serviam originalmente para segurar o morro.

reviews.author: Cl√°udia Ricci
reviews.text: Os Arcos do Bixiga fazem parte de uma importante estrutura arquitet√¥nica que marca a hist√≥ria dos imigrantes italianos em S√£o Paulo.

reviews.author: Rodrigo Marttie
reviews.text: Infelizmente esse patrim√¥nio hist√≥rico de S√£o Paulo est√° se tornando um dep√≥sito de lixo e uma mini-cracol√¢ndia.

name: Ihwa-dong Mural Village
editorialSummary: A series of walkways lined with colorful murals, mosaic-tiled staircases & metal sculptures.
address: 49 Naksan 4-gil, Jongno District, Seoul

reviews.author: Maria Ngo
reviews.text:
Lots of stairs! There are 32 listed murals. I liked them. It's free to visit and wander around the area. There is a map showing the murals. There are a few lookouts and such public places with a great view overlooking the city.
Depending on whether you started from above or below, the City wall walk is on the higher side.
This village has retained its old world charm with tiny buildings and some doorways that are around 5ft or less high.
There is a public toilet at the City wall side.
There are some coffee shops scattered through the village.
Please walk respectfully and quietly through this area.
Definitely not wheelchair accessible.

reviews.author: J R
reviews.text: This spot is definitely worth a visit! While the murals aren‚Äôt all that big and there‚Äôs not a ton to see, the walk up is really pleasant and offers a great view of the city and Namsan Tower. It‚Äôs a perfect little area if you‚Äôre looking for a scenic stroll. Our visit was made even better by the bonus of being greeted by a super cute and cuddly cat. Overall, it‚Äôs a nice, relaxing spot to enjoy the view and get a little fresh air, highly recommend it!

reviews.author: Pedro Vera Obrador
reviews.text: Uphill and with many steps but a beautiful place with interesting views. Full of bars and cafes

reviews.author: Merve Sahin
reviews.text: Not sure if it‚Äôs worth hiking up the hills, but if you want to then it‚Äôs a cozy little part of town.

reviews.author: Vicky E
reviews.text: Worth a visit here if you are a mural art lover. Mostly small paintings. Not a huge area but quite a long walk from the main road and a long flight of stairs to this place. Spend approximately an hour here.

reviews.author: Daphney Huang
reviews.text: Bukchon has preserved many Hanok buildings, and it feels good to walk around and imagine the life in the past. I highly recommend this place, but be careful about the volume when you go there, as there are still many residents living here.

name: Bukchon Palgyeong
address: Samcheong-ro, Samcheong-dong, Jongno District, Seoul

reviews.author: Abdulkarim ALZarouni
reviews.text:
Bukchon Palgyeong, or the "Eight Scenic Views of Bukchon," is a historical site in the heart of Seoul that offers a perfect blend of cultural heritage and breathtaking scenery. Nestled between Gyeongbokgung Palace and Changdeokgung Palace, this area is a treasure trove of traditional Korean hanok houses, narrow alleyways, and stunning views of the city and surrounding mountains.

Each of the eight scenic viewpoints provides a unique perspective, from panoramic cityscapes to charming glimpses of Seoul's historic past. As you wander through the quaint alleys, you can feel the blend of tranquility and vibrancy that makes Bukchon so special.

The area is also home to art galleries, tea houses, and cultural workshops, offering an immersive experience in Korean traditions. Whether you're a photographer looking for the perfect shot or a traveler seeking an authentic cultural experience, Bukchon Palgyeong will not disappoint.

I highly recommend visiting early in the morning or late afternoon to enjoy the peaceful atmosphere and capture the best light for photos.

reviews.author: Salami
reviews.text: So pretty. Be sure to be quiet however

reviews.author: Gavia D. J.
reviews.text: This isn't a must go. In fact, the locals aren't fond of the tourist influx and the houses are nice but not super impressive. I like Seoul but this is skippable place.

reviews.text: One of my favorite places in Korea. Wonderful place

reviews.text: Many Asian food cafe stalls are placed.

reviews.author: Ïù¥Î≥ëÌõà (Ïø®Í∞ÄÏù¥)
reviews.text:
Central Asia Street is a street in Gwanghui-dong, Jung-gu, Seoul, South Korea.
It was named this way because there are relatively many businesses with Central Asian themes in this area.

It was created as a street in the 1980s and 1990s when foreigners from the former Soviet Union began to gather, starting with the establishment of diplomatic relations between Korea and the Soviet Union. The main residents were from Russia, Mongolia, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, Kyrgyzstan, and Buryatia. Peddler and fabric brokers set up bases here by opening accommodations and currency exchange shops for transactions at the nearby Dongdaemun Market.

In 1997, the IMF foreign exchange crisis led to a boom in the area due to the low exchange rate, and Russian peddlers and Uzbek and Mongolian migrant workers who were fluent in Russian flocked there. However, when Russia imposed a moratorium in 1998, many Russians withdrew, and only Central Asian workers remained to open shops and restaurants, resulting in the area's current appearance. In 2022, a theme street creation project was carried out under the leadership of Jung-gu Office, and floors and guides with traditional carpet patterns were installed.

reviews.author: national_jiographic

name: Namsan Palgakjeong (Octagonal Pavilion)
address: 1-3 Yejang-dong, Jung District, Seoul

reviews.author: J ‚Ä¢ B ‚Ä¢
reviews.text: Namsan Palgakjeong is a peaceful retreat with stunning views of Seoul‚Äôs skyline. The octagonal pavilion‚Äôs intricate design adds a touch of tradition amidst the city buzz. While it can get busy, it‚Äôs a great spot to catch your breath after a hike or cable car ride. Stay for sunset if you can‚Äîthe blend of colors over the city is truly unforgettable and worth the visit.

reviews.author: Ayyagari Srikanth
reviews.text:
Nestled atop Namsan Mountain, Namsan Palgakjeong is an absolute gem! The octagonal pavilion offers breathtaking panoramic views of Seoul, especially at sunset when the city lights start twinkling. The atmosphere is peaceful, making it a great spot to pause and soak in the beauty of the city.

The short hike up is refreshing, and if you‚Äôre not up for walking, the cable car ride is a fun alternative. There‚Äôs a lively energy around the pavilion with visitors taking photos, street musicians playing soft melodies, and couples placing love locks nearby. It‚Äôs a wonderful blend of nature, culture, and city life.

Definitely a must-visit if you‚Äôre in Seoul! Just bring a jacket if you go in the evening‚Äîit can get a bit chilly up there.

reviews.author: Snoop Ee
reviews.text: Beautiful sunset. The haze made it possible to see the round and orange sun.

reviews.author: Jerald Kng
reviews.text: Iconic Pavilion, hard to miss when up here

reviews.author: Qu Sd
reviews.text:
Its another üÜì spot in same vicinity as namsan tower.

We came here during late afternoon early evening on a pretty sunny day. It was a nice spot to sit down and cool off and take in the views and people watch.

Its visually pleasing and wasnt crowded either given that it was pretty busy otherwise at the base of namsan.

Hope to see it during night time views whenever i visit next. (Hopefully soon)

name: Naksan Fortress Wall Trail
address: 23-3 Changsin 7-gil, Changsin-dong, Jongno District, Seoul

reviews.author: Dave Chagnon
reviews.text: Beautiful views of Seoul.  Very walkable wall with options to walk on a brick walkway or more closely to the wall more of a gravel path.  Bring plenty of water and snacks.  Not too many convenience stores near by once you get walking.

reviews.author: Shreyamsa Manjunath
reviews.text: The Naksan Fortress Wall Trail is a beautiful remnant of the city walls built during the Joseon period. It extends from the Heunginjimun gate to Hyehwamun, through Naksan park and many more interesting viewpoints. The climb is steep, but doable. Sunset views are good, night views with city lights are even better from the wall trail. The wall itself is lit up,asking for a very pretty picture! A plus is that it is not crowded, unlike many of the other attractions in Seoul. A must visit without a doubt!

reviews.author: Sabrina Tsai
reviews.text:
Very walkable trail and great view at night.
Recommend to take a taxi to a nearby spot tho as the way to the entrance is quite steep.

reviews.author: Roxana Castellanos
reviews.text:
As a solo female traveler, I was comfortable on this trail, both during the day and at sunset. If you get the chance, give it a try!

The walk was enjoyable. Keep in mind it's uphill, so it might feel like a bit of a workout. At a certain point, you come across a few cafes and restaurants. Which is nice to refresh and keep going.

During summer, towards the end of the trail, there's a rose field... do yourself a favor and smell the rosesü§ó

There are also a few good spots to sit and watch the sunset.

Interestingly, you can also discover this LOVE sculpture in South Korea.

reviews.author: Alex Kl√©nin
reviews.text:
I stumbled upon the Kiosko Morisco by accident while heading to the Geology Museum. Out of nowhere, I saw this massive, Arab-style pavilion‚Äîsomething totally unexpected in Mexico.

Up close, you can see it's mostly made of steel tubing, with intricate decorative elements. The entrance was taped off, but since a group of locals was clearly doing a full photo session inside, I figured it would be fine to step in as well.

That might have been a mistake. About 15 minutes later, as I stepped out, I was greeted by police officers. Without much explanation, they demanded to see my documents‚Äîapparently someone had reported a ‚Äúsuspicious gringo,‚Äù aka me.

In the end, nothing serious came of it. They jotted something down and let me go, but the whole thing left a bit of an aftertaste. So‚Ä¶ cheers from CDMX

Visiting time: first half of March 2024.
The Fountain of the Virgin is the central fountain of the Alameda Central Park and was built in 1853.
It is a female statue with a naked torso, which is supported by four tritons, a turtle and a pedestal with a double slab. The sculpture was made by an artist (apparently French) named Valdosin.
Alameda Central Park, with its 12 fountains, plays an important role in the lives of the city's residents. Officially created in 1592, it is the oldest public park in America.

name: Monumento Vicente Guerrero
address: C. San Fernando 3, Centro Hist√≥rico de la Cdad. de M√©xico, Guerrero, Cuauht√©moc, 06300 Ciudad de M√©xico, CDMX

reviews.author: Omar Cruz
reviews.text:
A magnificent monument dedicated to Vicente Guerrero: the last insurgent leader, declared a Distinguished Person of the Nation by decree in 1833.

The sculptural ensemble depicts a scene of the general dressed in his military uniform holding a saber in his right hand, the point pointing downward. I interpret this representation as an allegory of Justice, which only uses force when necessary. It places us in historical context the battles fought in pursuit of recognition for the new country and defense against foreign invasions, but also the urgent need for peace.

The figure stands on a base with a plaque in the center bearing the National Emblem and the name of Vicente Guerrero. It is guarded by steel bars.

It is located in the atrium of the San Fernando Church, a historic architectural structure of incalculable heritage value. Every Saturday, a small market is held in this space for the buying, selling, and exchanging of old and secondhand books.

It is located on Hidalgo Avenue, 600 meters from the STC Metro Revoluci√≥n station and 190 meters from the Hidalgo station, both on Line 2 of the system.

Unfortunately, it is a space that feels neglected and requires further maintenance.

name: Bow Barracks
address: H994+VGP, 1Bow St, Pilkhana, Kolkata, West Bengal 700012

reviews.author: J M
reviews.text:
Bow Barracks, located in the heart of central Kolkata, is a quaint locality steeped in history and tradition. Renowned as a hub for the Anglo-Indian community, this neighborhood has been home to generations of families, preserving a unique cultural heritage.

A visit to Bow Barracks is akin to a journey into the past, offering glimpses of its colonial-era architecture and an old-world charm that captivates all who wander through its lanes. The area comes alive during festive seasons, especially Christmas and Easter, with vibrant celebrations that reflect its rich cultural tapestry.

Adding to the allure is the warm hospitality of its residents, who welcome visitors with open arms. Complementing this is the delectable Anglo-Indian cuisine, which promises an unforgettable gastronomic experience. Bow Barracks remains a cherished part of Kolkata, a testament to the city's diverse history and traditions.

reviews.author: Soumik Ghosh
reviews.text:
Christmas in Kolkata is synonymous with Park Street.. Usually we visit Park Street every year before 25th Dec to immerse in the spirit of Christmas with the beautiful lights all around.. This year however we saw many posts about another Christmasy place in Kolkata - Bow Barracks..
So we put on our explorer hats and equipped with Google Maps set off to experience the festivities in that region.. The place is walking distance of around 5-10 mins from the Chandni Chowk Metro Station (gate 5)..

Bow Barracks stands in the central part of Kolkata. Today, it is still popular as an Anglo-Indian community, but the truth is people from various ethnicities live here and call it their forever home. As the name suggests, the barracks were built to shelter World War I soldiers. After the end of the war, these boxed apartments were left vacant, so the government turned them into residences for the Anglo-Indian community..

The red bricked buildings scream of multicultural history and the glittery lights and sparkly decorations welcomed us into a warm celebration spirit.. The place was beautifully decorated with lights, a Christmas tree in middle, the nativity scene exhibited in one side and both sides of streets lined with food stalls set up by the local people selling momos, wantons, noodles, chilli chicken, pork items, cakes, wines, etc.

We walked under the lights, clicked some selfies and photos, devoured fried wantons, steamed momos and chana cake (a speciality and must have). We also queued in and got our hands on wine cake from the very famous JN Barua (got to know from a few posts that this is a famous one).

All in all Bow Barracks lived up to our expectations and we truly experienced Christmas Vibes there... Will definitely visit next year as well..

reviews.author: akanchha kachhap
reviews.text: I visited here on 31 December and it was so so pretty. Very well decorated and a lot less crowded than places like Parkstreet on those days. If you want to go out and get some Christmas vibes without the crowd then this is definitely the place. You can also get food stalls on those days selling delicious snacks to munch on. A must visit place atleast once during the Christmas season.

reviews.author: BISWANATH MUDI
reviews.text:
Big Ben Kolkata, also known as the Metcalfe Hall Clock Tower, is an iconic landmark and architectural marvel located in Kolkata, India. While the name "Big Ben" is commonly associated with the clock tower in London, this structure in Kolkata has earned the nickname due to its resemblance to the famous landmark.

Architectural Importance:
Big Ben Kolkata holds significant architectural importance in the city. The tower combines various architectural styles. It showcases intricate detailing, grand proportions, and elegant ornamentation.

The clock tower stands at a height of 48 meters (157 feet) and features a Corinthian column design. The tower's exterior is adorned with decorative sculptures, including Greek mythological figures and British monarchs. The clock face, designed with Roman numerals, is an impressive feature of the tower. The tower's distinct design and meticulous craftsmanship make it an architectural gem in Kolkata.

Landmark and Tourist Attraction:
Big Ben Kolkata is one of the most recognizable landmarks in Kolkata and attracts both locals and tourists alike.

Tourists visit Big Ben Kolkata to admire its architectural splendor, capture photographs, and appreciate its historical significance. The tower stands as a testament to the British colonial era in India and reflects Kolkata's rich heritage. It has become an iconic symbol of the city, representing its cultural and architectural heritage.

Moreover, Big Ben Kolkata's central location makes it easily accessible to visitors. Its proximity to other notable attractions, such as the Victoria Memorial, Indian Museum, and St. Paul's Cathedral, enhances its appeal as a tourist destination. Visitors often include Big Ben Kolkata as part of their itinerary when exploring the historical and cultural landmarks of Kolkata.

In conclusion, Big Ben Kolkata holds immense architectural importance due to its blend of Victorian and classical styles, intricate detailing, and impressive proportions. As a landmark and tourist attraction, it serves as a visual reference point in Kolkata and represents the city's rich heritage. Whether you're interested in architecture, history, or simply exploring notable landmarks, Big Ben Kolkata is a must-visit destination in the city.
