reviews.author: –°–≤–µ—Ç–ª–∞–Ω–∞ –¶—ã–≥–∞–Ω–æ–≤–∞
reviews.text:
This is one of those houses that immediately catch my attention when I walk around Moscow. It looks like it came straight out of a fairy tale book.
The building was constructed in 1899-1902 according to the design of architect N. M. Proskurnin. The facades are decorated in the style of the late Italian Renaissance. And the fairytale Gothic clock tower faces Turgenevskaya Square.
Initially, it was a tenement house with spacious apartments with high ceilings. Each entrance had electric elevators, and an autonomous power plant in the basement provided the apartments with light, energy and hot water.
In Soviet times, there were communal apartments here.
Now the insurance company "Russia" is located here.

reviews.author: Saltets G
reviews.text: Luxurious buildings from the very beginning of the 20th century. They were built by the insurance company Rossiya as apartment buildings, and in Soviet times as communal apartments.

reviews.author: Andrey Belov
reviews.text: The house of the "Russia Insurance Company" is two blocks of apartment buildings built in Moscow in 1899-1902 for the "Russia" insurance company according to the design of the architect N. M. Proskurnin. They are located at the address: Sretensky Boulevard, 6/1, buildings 1 and 2, and occupy the entire block between Frolov, Bobrov and Milyutinsky Lanes. They have the status of a cultural heritage site of federal significance. Throughout the Soviet era, communal apartments were housed in this house. I have repeatedly visited two of my acquaintances whose apartments were located in the entrances facing Bobrov Lane. What can I say - before the revolution, the building was steep. The ceilings in the apartments were 5 meters high - you couldn't change a light bulb in a chandelier without a stepladder. Almost every apartment had a fireplace and a back entrance from a huge kitchen with a separate stairwell so that the servants did not cross paths with the masters. One of my friends' parents made a mezzanine in one of the rooms, where they arranged a nursery. And it was a separate huge three-room apartment. I was still in school and when I came to visit my friend, I was delighted with this solution. It seemed to me then that it was incredibly cool. I lived in an ordinary panel high-rise building. The second friend lived in a communal apartment with seven rooms, two of which belonged to his parents. And even this option was very good, since the house was located in the very center and 50 steps from the metro.

reviews.author: Di Vinograd
reviews.text: An incredibly beautiful house! Different from all sides! You can walk around it for hours, enchanted, with binoculars, a telescope and a camera. The residents come out and laugh when they run into another group of onlookers, that is, the locals are almost constantly laughing! Happy.

name: Pertsova House
editorialSummary: Unique early-20th-century art nouveau building with fairy tale‚Äìinspired architectural elements.
address: Kursovoy Pereulok, 1, Moskva, 119034

reviews.author: Ha≈ümet Babaoƒülu
reviews.text:
The story of building
Residential house of Pertsova, which is also known as a fairy-tale house, is one of the finest examples of Moscow art nouveau buildings constructed in 1905‚Äì07 by the architects Schnaubert B.N. and Zhukov N.K. The house itself was built based on a sketch of a talented artist Sergey Malyutin. Enamored of Russian folklore fabulous epos, he created not only the buildings but also the furniture and everyday objects. What made his creations unique was a sense of fairy-tale, with symbols and history he found in folk art. Malyutin also authored the most famous Russian souvenir‚Äì Matryoshka doll.

reviews.author: Santosh Deval
reviews.text:
An architectural creation that deserves the attention of even the most sophisticated tourists. Zinaida Pertsova, the official owner of the architectural masterpiece, was the wife of philanthropist and railway magnate Pyotr Pertsov. The entrepreneur built an apartment building in 1907, one part of which was intended for tenants of talented artists and performers, the second for his own residence. In 1922 Pertsov was arrested and the house was nationalized. Leon Trotsky and other military leaders lived in the mansion. Since the 1970s, GlavUpDK of the Russian Foreign Ministry has been located.

The attraction is included in many walking tours of the Russian capital. Unfortunately, an object of federal significance can only be viewed from the outside.

reviews.text: The memorial sign was installed on the site where the Temple of Boris and Gleb, demolished in 1930, stood. The church was first mentioned in the chronicle, speaking about the events of July 28, 1493 - about the great fire that broke out from a penny candle in the neighboring Church of St. Nicholas on the Sands. The first stone church in honor of Boris and Gleb was built in 1527, by order of Grand Duke Vasily III. This church was especially revered by his son Ivan the Terrible. Under him, in 1551, the Church of Boris and Gleb became one of the seven Moscow cathedrals. The temple was rebuilt in 1997, but not in its historical place, but a little closer to Znamenka Street.

reviews.text:
In the very center of the capital, a five-minute crawl from the Kremlin, on Moskvoretskaya embankment there is an abandoned building from the 18th century! Sad, sad...
And once upon a time this classic building was conceived as a charity shelter. In 1812 it survived the invasion of Napoleon and the Great Moscow Fire, received the wounded into its walls and the dead into its lands. After the revolution, it became the Palace of Labor (whatever that means), Bulgakov, Ilf, Kataev and Olesha worked here in the editorial office of the Gudok newspaper. In the 21st century, various academies of very important sciences were located here. And so...
But! The status of an architectural monument and cultural heritage site remains. So he will be resurrected!

reviews.text:
This is a favorite place for thousands of Muscovites and guests of the capital: fairs, exhibitions and just festivities attract a huge number of people. The square arose in the 1790s, after the demolition of wooden buildings. It is located in the Central Administrative District of Moscow between Tverskaya Street, Tversky Proyezd and Stoleshnikov Lane.

The monumental buildings of the square are a whole gallery covering different historical eras that have sunk into oblivion and exist today. Thanks to the preserved historical flavor, Tverskaya Square has a worthy place in the list of sights of the capital.

name: "El Pensador" de Rodin
editorialSummary: Set in an urban park, this sculpture is a signed reproduction of "The Thinker," by Auguste Rodin.
address: 1600 C1085, Av. de Mayo 1548, 1085 Cdad. Aut√≥noma de Buenos Aires

reviews.author: NK A
reviews.text:
Brought from Paris in 1907.  Acquired through the efforts of Eduardo Schiaffino, the first director of the National Museum of Fine Arts.
Displayed in front of the Congress Building during Argentina‚Äôs centennial independence celebrations in 1910.

reviews.author: antonios varzakis
reviews.text:
The sculpture was originally named The Poet , as it represented the Italian writer Dante Alighieri , author of the Divine Comedy. At the Monet - Rodin exhibition at the Galerie George Petit in 1889, Rodin dropped the identification with Dante and renamed it The Thinker; The Poet, Fragment of a Door.
At the request of the first director of the National Museum of Fine Arts, the painter and historian Eduardo Schiaffino, a bronze copy was made from the original model and signed by Rodin.
It arrived from Paris in 1907 and was inaugurated in November of that same year.

reviews.text:
This monument to the Carta Magna and Four Regions of Argentina is made entirely of bronze and Carrara marble. It was a donation from the Spanish community in celebration of the centenary of the Revoluci√≥n de Mayo of 1810. Although the founding stone was set in 1910, the sculpture was not finalized until 1927.

It takes a bot of effort to find a safe crossing to the statue, but it is well worth the effort.

Check out Wikipedia for a fascinating history of this interesting monument.

reviews.author: Jo√£o Fernandes
reviews.text: "El Loco Ch√°vez" was the first comic strip co-created by Carlos Trillo and Horacio Altuna, and was published daily on the back cover of Diario Clar√≠n for 12 years, between July 1975 and November 1987. Hugo "El Loco Ch√°vez" began as a foreign correspondent, but in 1976 the strip was set in Buenos Aires, and El Loco began working in the newspaper's editorial office. The comic deals with his work, his relationships with his colleagues and their wives, politics, soccer, and the country's social reality. On November 10, 1987, El Loco and his girlfriend, Pampita, left together to live in Spain, and the strip ended the following day.

reviews.author: Mauro Ormaechea
reviews.text: El Loco Ch√°vez is a series of comics published by the Argentine newspaper Clar√≠n from 1975 to 1987. The authors are the scriptwriter Carlos Trillo and the cartoonist Horacio Altuna. This duo also created the comics Las Puertitas del Sr. L√≥pez (1979) and El Ultimo Recreo (1982).

reviews.author: Graciela
reviews.text: The comic strip trail begins at Defensa and Chile (San Telmo) with the sculptures of Mafalda, Susanita, and Manolito. It continues along Chile to Balcarce, Belgrano Avenue, and then Juana Manso. From there, it continues along Marta Lynch Avenue, ending at the Museum of Humor on Los Italianos Avenue. Along the trail, you'll find, in addition to Mafalda, Isidoro Ca√±ones, Larguirucho and Super Hijitus, Mat√≠as, Don Fulgencio, Clemente, the Divito Girls, Patoruz√∫, Patoruzito and Isidorito, Gaturro, Don Nicola, Negraz√≥n and Chaveta, Di√≥genes and the Linyera, Langostino and Corina, Inodoro Pereyra and Mendieta, and the Giraffe. It's a lovely walk that makes you long for your childhood.

name: El mundo segun Mafalda
address: San Nicol√°s, C1084 Buenos Aires

reviews.author: alejandro gimenez
reviews.text:
The work "The world according to Mafalda", located in the combination corridor between lines A and D of the Buenos Aires Subway, is a tribute to the iconic character of Quino. This mural, made up of 375 ceramic pieces, captures the essence of Mafalda and her vision of the world.
The work is a recognition of the legacy of Joaqu√≠n Salvador Lavado Tej√≥n, "Quino", creator of Mafalda, a character that transcended borders and generations.
The mural allows passengers to enjoy Mafalda's reflections and humor during their transfer, turning the trip into a cultural experience.
The technique used in the creation of the mural, with ceramic pieces, provides artistic and lasting value to the work.
The scenes represented in the mural invite reflection on social and political issues, always with Mafalda's characteristic touch of humor.
This mural has become a cultural reference point within the Buenos Aires subway network, attracting tourists and locals alike.
In summary, "The world according to Mafalda" is a work that combines art, culture and humor, enriching the experience of users of the Buenos Aires Subway.
Qty. Autonomous of Buenos Aires, Argentina

name: Monumento del Emperador Trajano
address: Viamonte 1280, C1053ABZ Cdad. Aut√≥noma de Buenos Aires

reviews.author: antonios varzakis
reviews.text:
The bronze sculpture of the Roman emperor Marcus Ulpius Traianus (from 98 to 117), located in front of the Courts building is a prominent figure representing the sense of justice.  Trajan was famous for his sense of justice and his willingness to heed the demands of his subjects.
Inaugurated in 1961, during Arturo Frondizi's presidency, the statue was donated by the Latin Action Center of Rome to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the May Revolution. The bronze work, on a marble-clad masonry base, depicts the emperor standing, dressed in classic Roman armor, holding a papyrus in his left hand while raising his right arm as if delivering a speech to a crowd. The 3.5-meter-high figure dominates the plaza's landscape.

reviews.author: federico arce
reviews.text: The sculpture of Emperor Trajan located in Plaza Lavalle in Buenos Aires was inaugurated in 1936 as part of a series of monuments donated by the Italian government to celebrate the cultural ties between the two countries. The work, a classical-style bronze replica, represents the Roman emperor in a solemn attitude and was placed alongside other figures from the ancient world, such as Julius Caesar and Caesar Augustus, in the so-called Sculpture Walk of the Roman Republic. This initiative was part of a cultural policy promoted by Benito Mussolini's regime, which sought to spread the grandeur of the Roman legacy in countries with strong Italian immigration, such as Argentina. Since then, the statue of Trajan has adorned Plaza Lavalle, in front of the Palace of Justice, as a symbol of the ideal of a just, civilized, and militarily competent ruler. It is a pleasure to witness it.

reviews.author: Fabian Zeballos
reviews.text:
He was Roman emperor from 98 to 117 AD. A replica is on display in the Naples Museum.
This replica was donated in 1961 and is located in Piazza Lavalle in front of the Tribunale.

reviews.author: Matias Retamozo
reviews.text: The statue of Trajan is the only monument in the city of Buenos Aires that honors a Roman emperor. It is a replica of the one exhibited in the Popular Museum of Naples. It was donated to the city in 1961 by the Latin Action Center, on the occasion of the 150th anniversary of the May Revolution. The original base was made of marble and reproduced Trajan's Column in Rome from 112 AD. The current base is concrete. The rule of Emperor Trajan was marked, among other things, by the construction of enduring buildings and monuments in Rome such as the Trajan Forum, Trajan's Market and Trajan's Column. He was emperor between the years 98 and 117. His legacy, unlike other rulers, was appreciated. Remembered along with Augustus as the greatest emperors. He received the title of Optimus Princeps (The Best of Princes) by the Roman Senate. His legacy was so great that when a new emperor ascended to the throne, the Senate expressed the following wish "Felicior Augusto Melior Traiano", that is, "May he be luckier than Augustus and better than Trajan", since they symbolized the heights of the imperial stage.

address: 12A Adeleke St, Allen, Ikeja 101233, Lagos

reviews.author: Africa's Travelling Seed
reviews.text:
As a lover of museum and galleries, this spot was just okay. The tour guide was great and very knowledgeable about the history and songs of Fela Kuti. A musical political activist. However, it would have been nice to have some of his music playing in the background for those who knew little about this Nigerian legend. Also he was the only one working so he was up and down between the tour. It's definitely a good stoo if you're keen to know about Fela without reading it up on a Wikipedia page.

There's a rooftop bar where one can have drinks and souvenir shop at the bottom if you need a cool tee. They do have a better opportunity of living up the spaces as they feel dead and decaying. Maybe better lighting and a paintwork. But that's just my opinion.

For a die hard fan, I hear you could come at night and experience music and dance with other Fela fans. (to be confirmed, I'd call to ask when they host these festivals)

reviews.author: Adebayo Yewande
reviews.text:
I visited the late legendary Fela Anikulapo shrine and home in ikeja Lagos. The place holds a lot of memories and history about the legendary musician.

A fee of 1,000 naira is being collect as entrance fee and a guide takes people around to show what the place is about and narrates the history about the place.

We were taken around alongside some other tourist and we were show some of Fela‚Äôs ablum, his rooms which houses his personal items such as his saxophone, his clothes.

We were informed by the tour guide that his clothes have been there since his demise and we were also showed his shoes too.

He was such a stylish musician I can say.
We  were also taken upstairs, more like a rooftop where we saw a very big local pot called (ikokorin in Yoruba) which means ‚Äúiron pot‚Äù in English.

Some souvenirs are also called on the premises at different rates such as t-shirts, caps etc.

It is a nice place and it holds a lot of history.

name: Afro-brazilianculturalcenter
address: local government, 13 Catholic Mission St, Lagos Island, Lagos 101001, Lagos

reviews.author: JLA A
reviews.text:
Disappointed to give a 3 STAR because I specifically sought this place out and really wanted to learn more about Nigerian - Brazilian history. However, the tour guide didn't know the history -- basic things like when did slavery end! I also know a lot about the history and knew when the truth was being stretched but the tour guide kept arguing with me that they've been working there for 10 years so I should just "trust them".... üôÑ it's sad. So because of that we decide to downgrade from the N10k tour package to the N3k package rather than leave because we had already traveled from so far and I wanted to support the center.

The place needs work, but it's a gem in the rough. I really hope the management continues to make an effort to revam this place because it's such a great opportunity and good for the culture. We learned that the family single handedly saved some buildings from demolition so kudos to them. They also have a very nice and simple hostel available which is a lovely idea. Also found out that there are free Portuguese classes every Saturday for kids. These things should be highlighted.

Message to the owner: I congratulate your efforts, a civilian providing such a vital but neglected public service to Nigerian cultural heritage. Keep on going and don't let your vision decay!

Easy, cost effective recommendations:
- Improve your publicity--it's hard to even know this place exists and what it offers.
- Encourage your tour guides to know what they are talking about. Assuming you pay them, so they need to do their job properly.

reviews.author: Olugbenga Akinkugbe
reviews.text: Small but important centre rich with information on Afro-Brazilian community who returned after being enslaved, their experiences and influence on Lagos. Great tour by our great guide Omowunmi. Hope this place continues to receive support so it can preserve and share these stories.

reviews.text: Interesting historical place that explains the links between Brazil and the Yoruba culture however I was surprised that I was asked for 3kN at the end of the visit but I still paid, the guide wanted to continue the visit in another place where this time I was asked for 10k when I refused we tried to negotiate to 7k it is very sad and a shame that we end up haggling in order to make money on the history of our ancestors. reviews.author: Jummy Aminu
reviews.text:
It was my first time there and I did enjoy myself but my experience wasn‚Äôt great.
The beach is crowded and there‚Äôs literally no place for you to chill at the shore except you are paying to sit down. That‚Äôs right, you have to pay to sit down and there‚Äôs no room for you to put your mat at the shore because the sitting arrangement is literally to the bank of the ocean. Asides that, you can‚Äôt even stand in peace because there are people riding horses by the shore so you constantly have to run to give them space.
The worst past is the horses poo. They poo right on the shore where people are trying to swim or just put their feet‚Äôs in the water. It‚Äôs dirty and disgusting. Nonetheless, I took cool pictures and had to find a way to have a great time but I doubt I‚Äôll be visiting there again.

The experience was nice upon visitation.

They don't have much in terms of proper food; they sell mostly finger foods. Of all restaurants that approached us with their menu, just one had jollof rice as an option.

reviews.author: Michael
reviews.text:
So I spent the day at the beach. The wind blowing, sun setting and cool breeze across your face makes you feel really peaceful while you are here.This is a lovely beach that stretches miles along the blue Atlantic.

There‚Äôs ample parking space, enough security, a lot of restaurants you can eat from on the beach or at their store. There‚Äôs a pool with a kids pool and about 4 life guards on duty at a time. Plenty of showers and very clean toilets. The quality of the sun beds, chairs and cabanas are top notch. I really hope that is maintained.

All in all this is a place is the best beach in lagos in my humble opinion.

reviews.author: Emmanuel Oluyori
reviews.text:
The LCC Is an experience away from the lifeless "concrete and metal" city of Lagos. I must say, a good job is being done preserving the natural state of the wildlife, swamp and shrubbery. The canopy walk is one of the highlights, it is well maintained and very exciting to say the least.
I also like that there is a park where you can unwind at the end of the experience with family and friends. There are a lot of activities ranging from giant board games, mini basketball court, tropical drinks and more.
It is worth every penny and I'm honestly surprised it is not priced more.

reviews.author: Chukwuebuka Nnamuchi
reviews.text: I grew up in the outback of Lagos so I got used to forest and mangroves as a young chap. However, the LCC Mangrove is well conserved and those gangs of monkeys ain't kidding with you except if they know who's the bossü§£ü§£ü§£. The canopy walk is exhilarating, not for the faint-hearted ü§£ü§£ü§£ and it's the grand of the experience. The Lagos Conservation Center is worth the visit.

reviews.text: Wow! What an experience!!! I thought it was going to be a walk in the park, but I was pleasantly surprised. It was a very long walk and climb...scary, intriguing and exciting all at the same time. Never been in close proximity with monkeys... definitely worth another visit.

Have a thrilled day with families and friends.

reviews.text: The only thing good about this place was the ocean and my room. There was nothing aesthetically pleasing about environment.  However, my room overlooked the ocean which was a plus. I feel they need to address the overall look of the place to include fun activities and access to the beach unchaperoned. The meals were a rip off and not entirely tasty. I recall ordering for a Greek salad and this didnt even have olives and feta cheese.  I want to give kudos to the cleaners as they really cleaned up my room well and my bed was very comfortable.  My room also had a smart TV was comforting as I could watch my Netflix.

I couldn't use the WiFi, which was disappointing. There was an ongoing construction at the beach front, and I couldn't walk along the beach like I planned to. Water was going on and off, but the staff were responsive, I didn't get hot water in the taps, but I didn‚Äôt complain about it. The food was delicious, and the portions were generous. I suggest an additional AC in the bigger rooms to reduce the heat. I really love the decor and ambience.

name: Kreeda Junction
address: Double Rd, Sampangi Rama Nagara, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560027

reviews.author: Veerashekhara S
reviews.text:
Kreeda Junction in Bangalore is a must-visit destination for sports lovers and enthusiasts of all ages. Nestled in the vibrant city, this unique space celebrates India's rich sporting heritage while offering a dynamic and interactive experience for visitors. What truly sets Kreeda Junction apart is its dedication to honoring legendary sports personalities from Karnataka, including names like V Subhramanya, Virat Kohli, Rahul Dravid, Prakash Padukone, and Syed Kirmani.

The facility is thoughtfully designed, blending modern technology with nostalgic tributes. Visitors can engage with interactive exhibits that showcase the journey and achievements of icons such as Virat Kohli, whose rise from Delhi to international stardom has inspired millions, and Rahul Dravid, the ‚ÄúWall‚Äù of Indian cricket, who is revered for his technique and humility. The museum also highlights the finesse of Prakash Padukone in badminton, the wicket-keeping brilliance of Syed Kirmani, and the contributions of V Subhramanya, a key figure from Karnataka‚Äôs cricketing roots.

Beyond the exhibits, Kreeda Junction also offers workshops, simulation zones, and youth engagement programs that make it a hub for aspiring athletes. Whether you‚Äôre a cricket fanatic, a badminton buff, or simply someone who appreciates Indian sporting greatness, Kreeda Junction promises an enriching and inspiring experience. It‚Äôs a celebration of passion, perseverance, and sporting excellence.

address: WJ48+7F4 Madivala Lake, EWS Colony, BTM 2nd Stage, BTM Layout, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560076

reviews.author: Khwahish Gupta
reviews.text:
I visited the beautiful place with my family on a weekend evening.
There is no ticket and no waiting time to enter the premises. The campus is very large and green, and the lake is really beautiful. We took a stroll for sometime and then sat on a bench to enjoy the cool breeze and calmness near the lake.
There are good eateries also nearby so one can enjoy the food with the lake view as well.

reviews.author: Sumanta Ghosh
reviews.text: Beautiful and calm place. Well mentioned park. Good place for boating. They have designated places for parking. The weekend is crowded. Evening till 6:45pm they allow us to stay. Sunrise is amazing from there. A lot of people come for morning walks. The lake water is clean, In the evening you can see a lot of birds returning to their nest. For an adult entry fee is 10 rupees for 2hrs, and two wheeler charge is 15rupees. For boating 50 rupees per head for half an hour, till evening 6pm they allow for boating tickets. Verify of trees are there where you can sit and spare time. Washrooms are available within the park.

reviews.author: Nivedh G
reviews.text:
This is a very cozy place to visit in the early mornings as there will be very few peoples who came to jog or meditate.
It will get very crowded in the evening and there is no need to take any tickets for entry.
Camera photography is not allowed as they will ask you not to enter with the camera

reviews.author: SWAGATIRAJ PACKER and MOVERS
reviews.text:
Madiwala Lake in Bangalore offers a serene escape from the city's bustling life, and its boating experience is a highlight. The lake's tranquil waters provide the perfect setting for a leisurely boat ride. Visitors can rent paddle boats and rowboats, making it an ideal outing for families and couples alike. The lush greenery surrounding the lake enhances the experience, creating a peaceful atmosphere that allows you to connect with nature.

One of the unique aspects of Madiwala Lake is its connection to the natural rubber industry. The lake is bordered by rubber plantations, and this synergy between the lake and the rubber trees is fascinating. It's a reminder of the essential role rubber plays in our daily lives, from tires to various everyday products. The combination of the lake's beauty and the adjacent rubber plantations adds an educational element to the visit.

In conclusion, Madiwala Lake's boating experience offers a refreshing break from the urban hustle and bustle. Its scenic beauty, coupled with the proximity to rubber plantations, makes it a must-visit destination. Whether you're seeking relaxation or an opportunity to learn more about natural rubber, this place has something for everyone, earning it a positive and memorable review.

reviews.author: Rupam Biswas
reviews.text:
It‚Äôs wonderful place to visit. It has boat rides and a beautiful view of sunset and also you can enjoy the place through walking if you are walk-enthusiast.

You may have to wait to get tickets of entrance and boat ride as well if you are visiting on weekends. Overall, it‚Äôs a must visit place with family, friends and anyone.

reviews.text:
relaxed outing ,
Surrounded by trees, natural elements, and open space, the setting immediately calms the senses. The layout is thoughtfully designed to preserve the natural charm while offering comfort and accessibility. The gentle sounds of birds, rustling leaves, and the occasional breeze create a soothing, almost meditative atmosphere.

reviews.author: PRASANNA KUMAR K M
reviews.text:
Manchanabele Dam is a hidden gem for anyone who loves nature, peace, and scenic views. Located just a short drive from Bangalore, it offers a perfect weekend getaway from the city's chaos. The drive itself is quite scenic, and once you arrive, the calm waters surrounded by lush hills create a truly serene atmosphere.

Great spot for photography, picnics, or just relaxing by the water. If you arrive early in the morning or around sunset, the views are especially magical. There are a few trails around the area for those who enjoy light trekking or exploring.

Just a heads-up: swimming is not allowed, and it‚Äôs best to pack your own snacks or water, as there are limited facilities nearby. Respect the environment‚Äîplease don‚Äôt litter!

Overall, Manchanabele Dam is a peaceful and beautiful place that‚Äôs definitely worth a visit if you‚Äôre in or around Bangalore.
